Fig. 1 Scheme for the preparation of CAOC catalysts. Fig. 2 X-ray diffraction pattern of CAOC catalysts (a, b) [Al/C (Ⅰ), Ce/C (Ⅱ), CAOC-1 (Ш), CAOC-2 (Ⅳ), CAOC-3 (Ⅴ), CAOC-4(Ⅵ)], and Raman spectra of CAOC catalysts (c, d). Fig. 3 SEM images of CAOC-1 (a-c); elemental map of Ce, Al, O, and C (d-g); TEM (h) and HR-TEM (i) images; and its SAED pattern (j). Fig. 4 BET plots of (a) CAOC-1, (b) CAOC-2, (c) CAOC-3, (d) CAOC-4. Fig. 5 (a) EPR spectra of CAOC-1, (b) TGA plot of crude CAOC-1. Fig. 6 XPS analysis of CAOC-1: high-resolution spectra of (a) Ce 3d, (b) Al 2p, (c) O 1 s, and (d) C 1 s. Fig. 7 Conversion of 5-HMF and yield of 2,5-FDCA and other oxidation products: (a) using different CAOC catalysts; and using CAOC-1 (b) at different HMF: TBHP mole ratio, (c) at different reaction temperatures and (d) at different reaction durations. Reaction conditions: (a) 5-HMF (1 mmol), catalyst (50 mg), DMSO (5 g), TBHP (9 mmol), temp (120 °C), 24 h, (b) 5-HMF (1 mmol), CAOC-1 (50 mg), DMSO (5 g), temp (120 °C), 24 h, (c) 5-HMF (1 mmol), CAOC-1 (50 mg), DMSO (5 g), TBHP (9 mmol), 24 h, (d) 5-HMF (1 mmol), CAOC-1 (50 mg), DMSO (5 g), TBHP (9 mmol), temp (120 °C). Fig. 8 (a) Effect of CAOC-1 catalyst loadings (b) Reusability of the CAOC-1 catalyst: 5-HMF conversion and 2,5-FDCA yield. (c) Synthesis of 5-HMF from fructose using different catalysts, (d) One pot, Two-steps, synthesis of 2,5-FDCA from 5-HMF using different catalysts. Reaction conditions: (a) 5-HMF (1 mmol), CAOC-1 catalyst, DMSO (5 g), TBHP (9 mmol), temp (120 °C), 24 h, (b) 5-HMF (1 mmol), CAOC-1 (50 mg), DMSO (5 g), temp (120 °C), 24 h, (c) Fructose (1 mmol), Catalyst (50 mg), DMSO (5 g), 2 h, under N2, (d) First step: Fructose (1 mmol), Catalyst (50 mg), DMSO (5 g), temp (120 °C), 2 h, Second Step: TBHP (9 mmol), Temp (120 °C), 24 h. Graphical abstract Using tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) as a low-cost oxidant, we synthesized, characterized, and evaluated heterogeneous bifunctional oxide catalysts composed of the non-noble metals Ce and Al in specific molar ratios, supported on glucose-derived carbon, for the conversion of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (2,5-FDCA) in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO). TBHP offers two advantages: it functions as an oxidant and generates tert-butanol, a valuable industrial solvent. We fully investigated catalyst loading, temperature, 5-HMF:TBHP molar ratio, reaction time, and reuse impact on product yield while correlating with the catalyst’s textural and chemical properties. CAOC-1, the best catalyst, achieved 98 % conversion, 82.0 % yield, and 83.54 % selectivity of 2,5-FDCA in optimal conditions (5-HMF (1 mmol), TBHP (9 mmol), DMSO (5 gm), CAOC-1 (50 mg), Temp (120 °C), 24 h), with minimal yield reduction over five reuse cycles. We used the bifunctional CAOC-1 in a one-pot, two-step system to directly transform fructose to 2,5-FDCA under mild conditions (fructose (1 mmol), TBHP (9 mmol), DMSO (5 gm), CAOC-1 (50 mg), temp (120 °C), 26 h) with minimal process modifications. The yield and selectivity of 2,5-FDCA were 80.26 % and 83.94 %, respectively. We proposed mechanistic pathways for dehydration and oxidation reactions, highlighting the catalyst’s bifunctional nature in facilitating high 2,5-FDCA yields from fructose and 5-HMF. The formation of the distinct redox environment of Ce and Al on carbon, the various oxidation states, and the oxygen vacancies in the CAOC-1 catalyst—all of which most likely operate as base-free oxidation active sites. One-pot reaction processes involve bifunctional CAOC-1 catalysts, –OH, and redox active sites (Ce), which play a significant role in dehydration and oxidation reactions, respectively. 2,5-FDCA is crucial to produce polyethylene 2,5-furandicarboxylate (PEF), a sustainable bioplastic and alternative to PET. Keywords 3D sphere mesoporous carbon 2,5-FDCA Oxygen vacancies Bifunctional-CeO2-Al2O3 oxides Synergistic effect Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Concerns over global warming and the ongoing depletion of fossil resources have intensified efforts to develop renewable natural resources to meet the growing global demand for fuels and chemicals [1]. Renewable and sustainable energy sources—such as geothermal, hydroelectricity, wind, solar, and biomass—offer viable alternatives to fossil fuels [2]. Among these, biomass is particularly attractive as an organic carbon source [3]. In the context of sustainable development and green chemical processes, biomass transformation is gaining increasing attention as an efficient renewable pathway for producing essential chemicals, polymer precursors, and petroleum-derived commodities. As the primary component of lignocellulosic biomass, cellulose is both renewable and inedible, making it an ideal feedstock for conversion into a diverse range of platform and high-value compounds [4]. Among the platform chemicals derived from C6-based carbohydrates, 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) is considered one of the most industrially significant due to its role as a precursor for various bio-based products such as chemicals and fuels [5,6]. This versatility arises from its two reactive functional groups—an aldehyde and a hydroxyl moiety—which enable participation in oxidation, reduction, condensation, and hydrogenation reactions [7]. Different oxidation pathways can convert 5-HMF into valuable compounds such as 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF), 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (HMFCA), 5-formyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (FFCA), and 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (2,5-FDCA), as illustrated in Scheme 1 . Among the derivatives of 5-HMF, 2,5-FDCA has been recognized by the U.S. Department of Energy as one of the Top 12 most important bio-based molecules. As a monomer, 2,5-FDCA is increasingly attracting global attention for its role in bioplastic production. It serves as a key building block for synthesizing polyethylene furanoate (PEF), polyamides, and polyesters. PEF, in particular, is a promising bio-based alternative to petroleum-derived polyethylene terephthalate (PET) for manufacturing soft drink bottles, food packaging materials, and other high-value products [8]. The rising commercial significance of 2,5-FDCA has renewed interest in its production from bio-based 5-HMF. Both homogeneous and heterogeneous noble metal catalysts—such as Pd, Pt, Au, and Ru—have been explored for oxidizing 5-HMF to 2,5-FDCA [8]. However, homogeneous Co/Mn/Br catalysts pose challenges related to catalyst recovery, toxicity, corrosive bromine, and limited reusability [9,10]. Meanwhile, heterogeneous catalysts often suffer from active site leaching into the reaction medium, leading to early deactivation and unsuitability for extended reaction periods [11]. Additionally, the high cost of noble metals in conventional heterogeneous catalysts limits their large-scale application in 2,5-FDCA synthesis [12,13]. To address these challenges, researchers have successfully developed low-cost heterogeneous catalysts incorporating non-noble metals. For example, Fe-, Co–, and Mn-based catalysts have demonstrated high efficiency in 5-HMF oxidation while exhibiting strong resistance to leaching and deactivation [14]. Due to its natural abundance and low cost, cerium (Ce) is a promising material for developing inexpensive heterogeneous catalysts. Ce-based catalysts exhibit high catalytic activity due to their multiple oxidation states, chemical stability, tunable acid-base properties, and exceptional oxygen storage capacity, which arises from their rich oxygen vacancies [15]. Ce oxides possess well-defined redox properties and feature unique Lewis’s acid-base active sites [16,17]. Furthermore, supporting metal species on the ceria surface significantly enhances their redox behavior. The strong interaction between Ce and the supported metal species leads to the formation of multiple catalytically active sites at their interface, making them highly effective for multi-step biomass transformation processes [18]. Bimetallic composite catalysts are an area of extensive research, as they generate a unique synergistic effect between two metal components at the atomic level while combining their advantageous properties. This synergy often results in superior catalytic performance compared to monometallic counterparts across a range of mixed catalytic reactions [19]. Previously, we demonstrated that Ce-Al oxide catalysts effectively and selectively convert fructose to 5-HMF, achieving a 91 % yield of 5-HMF with 95 % fructose conversion [20]. The successful development of this efficient bimetallic catalyst is economically advantageous, as both Ce and Al are relatively abundant and inexpensive. In this study, we further investigate the application of a Ce-Al bimetallic heterogeneous catalyst for a one-pot reaction system integrating two key processes: (1) the dehydration of fructose to 5-HMF and (2) the oxidation of 5-HMF to 2,5-FDCA. However, our focus in this report is primarily on the role of Ce-Al oxides in the oxidation step. The hydrothermal synthesis method was selected as it enables the uniform dispersion of Ce-Al mixed oxides on a carbon support, resulting in homogeneously structured particles—an essential factor for achieving high catalytic efficiency. By leveraging the combined advantages of CeO2 and Al2O3, such as high redox activity, strong catalytic performance, and large surface area, we aimed to develop low-cost, highly efficient, oxygen-deficient, and highly selective catalysts for 5-HMF conversion to 2,5-FDCA. CeO2 and Al2O3, serving as active components, were immobilized on carbon at varying loadings to produce Ce-Al oxide composites supported on carbon (CAOC). The incorporation of carbon as support offers additional benefits for the oxidation step, including enhanced dispersion of active sites, improved catalyst stability under oxidative conditions, and facilitated electron transfer due to its conductive properties. These factors collectively contribute to improved catalytic performance and selectivity [12,21]. Additionally, Ce plays a crucial role in supplying reactive oxygen at the metal-support interface, ensuring a high oxidation state in metal catalysis [16], while Al enhances reactivity, tunability, and product selectivity. We employed CAOC composite catalysts to oxidize 5-HMF to 2,5-FDCA in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) after systematically screening potential solvents and oxidants, ultimately selecting tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) as the stoichiometric oxidizing agent. TBHP is highly reactive, and its reduction product, tert-butyl alcohol, can be easily separated from the reaction mixture, making it an excellent oxidant [22]. We conducted a comprehensive investigation of CAOC’s catalytic performance by varying CeO2 loadings to examine how the interactions between CeO2 and Al2O3, the formation of oxygen surface vacancies, and these variations influenced catalytic activity in 5-HMF oxidation. Notably, we carried out the oxidation step without using an external base, distinguishing our approach from many previous 5-HMF oxidation studies. Using fructose as the starting material, we achieved a significant 2,5-FDCA yield of approximately 80.26 % and selectivity (83.94 %) in a one-pot reaction system. Even after multiple reaction cycles and reactivations, the recovered CAOC catalyst maintained its catalytic activity. This approach offers an energy-efficient and environmentally friendly route for producing 2,5-FDCA from bio-based feedstocks. As of this writing, the one-pot fructose-to-2,5-FDCA yield obtained using CAOC is the highest reported among all heterogeneous catalysts. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials All analytical-grade reagents were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich and Alfa Aesar (Korea) and used without further purification. These included fructose (C6H12O6), 5-HMF, 2,5-FDCA, FFCA, DFF, aluminum nitrate nonahydrate (Al(NO3)3·9H2O), cerium (Ш) nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O), DMSO, 70 % aqueous TBHP, 30 % aqueous H2O2, urea (NH2CONH2), glucose (C6H12O6), and glacial acetic acid. Deionized (DI) water (18.2 MΩ·cm−1 at 25 °C) was processed using a Millipore Milli-Q system. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts CAOC catalysts were synthesized via a hydrothermal process [23]. Specifically, Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (2.00 g) and Al(NO3)3·9H2O (1.72 g) were mixed in ultrapure water (100 mL) to achieve the target Ce/Al molar ratio, along with urea (1.00 g) and glucose (1.00 g). The mixture was stirred vigorously at 25 °C for 30 min before being transferred to a 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, which was then sealed and placed in a temperature-controlled electric oven. Hydrothermal treatment was conducted at 180 °C for 24 h, yielding a black slurry. After cooling to room temperature, the solid product was collected via vacuum filtration, washed several times with ultrapure water and methanol, and dried at 80 °C overnight. Finally, the dried material was calcined in air at 500 °C for 5 h. The synthesized catalysts were denoted as CAOC-n, where n represents the Ce/Al molar ratio. Accordingly, CAOC-1, CAOC-2, CAOC-3, and CAOC-4 were prepared using this method. Additionally, monometallic Ce/C and Al/C catalysts were synthesized under identical conditions, while pure Al2O3 and CeO2 were prepared following similar procedures. Fig. 1 illustrates the CAOC synthesis process. 2.3 Catalytic reaction processes 2.3.1 Dehydration of fructose to 5-HMF A liquid-phase catalytic dehydration reaction was performed using a standard procedure in a round-bottom flask (RBF) equipped with a magnetic stirrer and placed over a hot plate with an oil bath. Fructose (1 mmol, 180 mg), DMSO (5 g), and CAOC catalyst (50 mg) were added to the RBF, which was fitted with a reflux condenser connected to an N2-balloon. The reaction was conducted at 120 °C for 2 h. Afterward, samples were collected and analyzed using a Waters HPLC system. 2.3.2 Oxidation of 5-HMF to 2,5-FDCA 5-HMF (1 mmol, 126 mg) was dissolved in DMSO (5 g) in a 50 mL two-neck RBF at room temperature and stirred at 600 rpm. CAOC catalyst (50 mg) was then added, followed by the dropwise addition of TBHP (9 mmol). A reflux condenser was fitted to one neck of the flask to prevent solvent evaporation. The reaction was conducted at 120 °C in a preheated oil bath under continuous stirring (600 rpm), with reaction time starting upon immersion of the flask in the oil bath. After completion, the catalyst was removed by centrifugation, and a portion of the liquid was diluted to a set volume for HPLC analysis. 2.3.3 “One-pot, two-step” synthesis of 2,5-FDCA from fructose In a one-pot, two-step approach, fructose (1 mmol, 180 mg), CAOC catalyst (50 mg), and DMSO (5 g) were added to a 50 mL RBF. The dehydration reaction was performed under an N2 atmosphere at 120 °C for 2 h. Subsequently, the oxidation step was initiated by introducing air and adding TBHP (9 mmol) dropwise at 120 °C for 24 h. After completion, the mixture was cooled to room temperature, the catalyst was separated by centrifugation, and an aliquot of the reaction mixture was analyzed using a Waters HPLC system. 2.4 Product analysis methods Reaction samples were collected at predetermined intervals during both oxidation and dehydration processes. For fructose dehydration, samples were diluted with DI water and filtered through a 0.22 μm PTFE membrane filter. HPLC analysis was conducted using a Waters HPLC system equipped with a Bio-Rad Aminex HPX-87H column (300 mm × 7.8 mm) and a refractive index detector (2414 RI). The mobile phase consisted of 5 mM H2SO4 at a flow rate of 0.6 mL·min−1, with the column maintained at 60 °C. Fructose conversion and 5-HMF yield were calculated using standard equations Eqs. (1) and (2) and calibration curves derived from external standards. The XRD patterns of Ce/C and Al/C reference materials, along with those of CAOC catalysts with varying Ce/Al molar ratios, are presented in Fig. 2 a and b. Despite being composed of nearly identical chemical species, the CAOC catalysts exhibit notable variations in their diffraction patterns, underscoring the influence of the Ce/Al molar ratio on their structure and configuration, which ultimately affects their catalytic performance. For the reference catalysts, the use of a single metal with carbon support results in distinct peaks. Al/C exhibits amorphous peaks at 2θ values of 19.40°, 31.91°, 37.40°, 39.40°, 45.86°, 60.80°, 66.96°, and 85.09°, corresponding to the (220), (311), (222), (400), (511), (440), and (444) lattice planes of Al2O3, as per JCPDS No. 00–010-0425 [24]. Ce/C, on the other hand, displays sharp diffraction peaks at 28.46°, 33.04°, 47.50°, 56.45°, 59.08°, 69.50°, 76.75°, 79.01°, and 88.33°, which align with the (111), (200), (220), (311), (222), (400), (331), (420), and (422) crystal planes of the cubic CeO2 structure, as confirmed by JCPDS No. 00–034-0394 ( Fig. 2 a) [17]. In the case of CAOC-1, distinct crystalline peaks corresponding to the CeO2 phase are observed, alongside an amorphous Al2O3 phase, indicating a mixed structure (Fig. 2 a). Notably, CAOC-1 exhibits sharp, well-defined diffraction peaks at 2θ values of 28.46°, 33.04°, 47.50°, 56.45°, 59.08°, 69.50°, 76.75°, 79.01°, and 88.33°, which precisely correspond to the (111), (200), (220), (311), (222), (400), (331), (420), and (422) crystal planes of the cubic CeO2 structure, as verified by JCPDS No. 00–034-0394 [17]. The presence of prominent CeO2 diffraction peaks in CAOC-1 strongly suggests the formation of highly crystalline CeO2 with a well-defined face-centered cubic (FCC) fluorite structure (space group Fm3m). Additionally, broad, low-intensity peaks indicate the presence of amorphous carbon and Al2O3, suggesting that carbon exists in significant amounts in an amorphous form within CAOC-1 [25]. This lack of crystallinity is advantageous for catalyst development, as it introduces more surface defects and lattice displacements, potentially increasing the number of catalytically active sites [26]. Notably, Al2O3 peaks are not prominently visible in CAOC-1, likely due to agglomeration (Fig. 2 b). This may be attributed to the smaller ionic radius of Al3+ (0.54 Å) compared to Ce4+ (0.92 Å), leading to a slight reduction in the lattice constant of CAOC-1 relative to that of CeO2. This observation suggests the possible incorporation of some Al3+ ions into the CeO2 lattice [27]. For CAOC-2, CAOC-3, and CAOC-4, the absence of Al2O3 peaks in their XRD patterns strongly indicates the successful incorporation of Al3+ ions into the CeO2 lattice, replacing Ce4+ and forming an integrated structure. This incorporation leads to progressively weaker and nearly undetectable Al2O3 peaks as the Ce/Al molar ratio increases, resulting in peak overlap between CeO2 and Al2O3. Additionally, the low concentration or high dispersion of Al2O3 may contribute to its diminished visibility. The crystalline of CAOC-2, CAOC-3, and CAOC-4 improves through this process, as evidenced by their XRD patterns, which exhibit stronger and narrower peaks compared to CAOC-1. Variations in crystallite size were determined using the Scherrer equation ( Table 1 ), revealing that the crystalline size of the main CeO2 phase increases from 11.35 nm (CAOC-1) to 15.70 nm (CAOC-2), 19.40 nm (CAOC-3), and 37.88 nm (CAOC-4). These differences indicate a strong interaction between Ce and Al, which enhances the growth of the crystalline CeO2 phase. Thus, co-precipitation at different Ce/Al ratios yields distinct physical and structural properties [27]. Despite having the smallest crystallite size, CAOC-1 exhibits the smallest pore size, the largest pore volume, and the highest surface area, facilitating better dispersion of active species (Table 2 ). As a result, CAOC-1 demonstrated the best catalytic performance among the CAOC catalysts. To further characterize the surface and bulk structures and identify oxide phases of CeO2 and Al2O3 in CAOC-1, CAOC-2, CAOC-3, and CAOC-4, Raman spectroscopy analysis was conducted. The Raman spectra for all CAOC catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 c, where CAOC-1 exhibits the highest degree of amorphous character. The bands at 464 cm−1 and 324 cm−1 in the CAOC-1 spectrum correspond to the vibrational modes F2g and Eg, respectively [16]. The vibrational mode at 464 cm−1 is characteristic of the cubic fluorite structure of CeO2, while the bands at 324 cm−1 and 835 cm−1 indicate the presence of the γ-Al2O3 phase [28,29]. Additionally, the weak peak at 263 cm−1, attributed to the Eg mode, suggests the presence of an amorphous α-Al2O3 or amorphous Al(OH)3 structure [30]. All CAOC catalysts exhibit a broadband characteristic of highly amorphous carbon ( Fig. 2 d). The sp2 carbon band appears at lower wavenumbers (1180 cm−1 and 1335 cm−1) [31–34]. The downward shift of this band, attributed to the highly amorphous nature of Al(OH)3 and carbon, strongly suggests a potential interaction between CeO2 and Al(OH)3 species in the CAOC-1 catalyst [20]. Notably, the interaction between CeO2 and Al2O3 species may have shifted the prominent A1g band in CAOC-1 to higher wavenumbers compared to pure CeO2. At ambient temperature, the F2g band is located at 464 cm−1. Due to the excellent symmetry of the CeO2 structure and Ce–O bonds, this main band is also highly intense. The Raman results corroborate the XRD analysis, confirming the observed structural characteristics. Additionally, the peaks at 464 and 595 cm−1 correspond to the F2g symmetric stretching vibration mode and the defect-induced D mode of the cubic CeO2 fluorite phase, respectively. The relative oxygen vacancy concentration was estimated using the 464/595 cm−1 band intensity ratio [23,35]. The ID/IF2g intensity ratio, indicative of oxygen vacancies, is provided for all CAOC catalysts in Table S1 . Among these, CAOC-1 exhibits the highest oxygen vacancy concentration (0.079), surpassing CAOC-2, CAOC-3, and CAOC-4. The increased oxygen vacancies in mixed oxide catalysts result from synergistic doping. Raman spectroscopy further confirms that CeO2-containing mixed oxide nanocrystals retain a cubic phase incorporating Ce3+ cations. In CAOC-1, the likelihood of forming a cubic phase with Ce3+ is enhanced by Al3+ integration Al3+into the CeO2 lattice, which promotes oxygen vacancy formation [36]. These vacancies may arise through a Frenkel-type defect mechanism due to the substantial size difference between metal and oxygen species [23]. The oxygen vacancies correspond to the peak at 595 cm−1 in the Raman spectra of CAOC-1. Raman analysis further confirmed their presence, which was also supported by EPR analysis (Fig. 5 a), where the observed g value (g = 1.96) indicates surface oxygen vacancies. These defects are strongly believed to play a crucial role in enhancing catalytic activity and improving reaction performance. 3.1.2 SEM and TEM analyses FE-SEM images were obtained to visualize the surface morphology of CAOC catalysts, with those of CAOC-1 displayed in Fig. 3 a–c. The images clearly show that CAOC-1 consists of uniformly sized spherical particles. EDX mapping images (Fig. 3 d–g) confirm the presence of Ce, Al, O, and C in CAOC-1, while the EDX plot in Fig. S12 provides the elemental atomic composition ratios of these elements. These results confirm the successful synthesis of a carbon-supported bimetallic composite catalyst with a predominantly spherical and hemispherical morphology [37]. Additionally, they suggest that the thermal treatment used in the synthesis process leads to minimal elemental loss. SEM images of CAOC catalysts prepared at different Ce/Al molar ratios Fig. S1 reveal variations in morphology. Catalysts with higher Ce content than Al exhibit thicker, more agglomerated, and irregularly shaped nanoparticles. In contrast, CAOC-1 maintains a nanoball-like morphology, which aligns with several literature reports [38,39]. To further analyse the structural characteristics, we conducted TEM imaging of CAOC-1, as shown in Fig. 3 h–j. All CAOC catalysts exhibit ball-like and hemispherical structures with relatively uniform sizes. Notably, particle size increases with higher Ce/Al ratios, likely due to enhanced cohesion when the particle surface is primarily composed of Ce oxides. This increased cohesion causes adjacent particles to fuse in catalysts with high Ce/Al ratios. However, in CAOC-1, the particles appear uniformly sized with no visible fusion, suggesting that a 1:1 Ce/Al molar ratio is optimal for producing uniform, sphere-shaped carbon-supported bimetallic oxide composite catalysts. The internal structure and interplanar distances of CAOC-1 were further characterized using HR-TEM. As shown in Fig. 3 i, the HR-TEM image depicts the atomic arrangement within the crystal structure [40]. The interplanar spacing of the (111) lattice plane in the fluorite CeO2 structure was measured at 0.31 nm, supporting the SAED pattern results (Fig. 3 j) and aligning with XRD analysis findings. 3.1.3 BET analyses Table 2 summarizes the BET surface area, pore size, and pore volume of the CAOC catalysts. The results indicate that pore size and surface area follow direct and inverse trends, respectively, with the Ce/Al ratio. Specifically, CAOC-1 exhibits the smallest pore size (14.08 nm) and the highest surface area (217 m2 g−1), while CAOC-4 has the largest pore size (61.43 nm) and the lowest surface area (95 m2 g−1). Although the pore volume data do not follow a strict trend, it generally decreases with increasing Ce/Al ratio, with CAOC-1 showing the largest pore volume (0.57 cm3 g−1) and CAOC-4 the lowest (0.23 cm3 g−1). These variations in textural properties, resulting from changes in the Ce/Al ratio, provide further evidence that strong interactions between Ce and Al species in CAOC significantly influence the physical structure of the final materials and ultimately define their catalytic performance. Fig. 4 a–d presents the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of the CAOC catalysts, which exhibit Type IV isotherms with H1 hysteresis loops. This indicates a mesoporous structure with a narrow pore size distribution [41]. Such meso-porosity is advantageous in catalysis, as it enhances mass transfer efficiency and contributes to superior catalytic performance. 3.1.4 FT-IR analyses Fig. S2 illustrates the FT-IR spectra of the CAOC catalysts, revealing that they contain essentially the same functional groups. The broad peak at 3400 cm−1 corresponds to –OH groups, while peaks at 2920 cm−1 and 1380 cm−1 represent C–H stretching and bending modes, respectively [42]. The CO vibration of ketones, esters, aldehydes, or carboxylic acids appears at 1702 cm−1, whereas the CC bond of alkenes or aromatic rings is observed at 1619 cm−1. Although the functional groups remain consistent across the catalysts, variations in peak intensity indicate differences in their abundance. Notably, the most significant deviation occurs in CAOC-1, where peaks in the C–O region (1000–1300 cm−1) are considerably weaker than those in the other catalysts. Meanwhile, stretching vibrations of Ce–O and Al–O are likely responsible for the weak peaks between 510 cm−1 and 724 cm−1 [20,43]. Additionally, the broad, weak bands in the 550–850 cm−1 region correspond to various metal–oxygen vibrational modes. These findings align with the chemical species identified through XRD analysis. 3.1.5 TGA To determine the optimal calcination temperature for the catalysts, we investigated the thermal degradation of crude CAOC material via TGA. The degradation profile, shown in Fig. 5 b, exhibits three distinct mass loss stages. The first stage, occurring between 50 °C and 250 °C with a mass loss of approximately 4.74 %, is primarily attributed to moisture release [17]. The second stage, with a mass loss of ∼ 17.27 % between 250 °C and 300 °C, likely results from the decomposition of nitrate salts. The third stage, between 300 °C and 450 °C, accounts for a 12.69 % mass loss, which can be ascribed to the elimination of nitrate groups [44]. Over the entire degradation process, the total weight reduction was approximately 34.7 %, with no significant mass loss observed beyond 450 °C. Based on this thermal profile, we selected 500 °C as the calcination temperature. Notably, crude CAOC, initially dark brown, turned yellowish after thermal treatment, indicating the formation of high-purity bimetallic nanoparticles. 3.1.6 XPS analysis of the CAOC-1 catalyst To further investigate the surface chemistry of CAOC-1, we conducted an XPS analysis to confirm its elemental composition and valence states. The wide-scan XPS spectrum of CAOC-1 is presented in Fig. S3 , with surface atomic composition data summarized in Table S3 . High-resolution spectra and their deconvolutions for individual elements are shown in Fig. 6 . The results reveal peaks corresponding to Ce 3d, Al 2p, O 1 s, and C 1 s. Fig. 6 a illustrates the deconvolution of the Ce 3d spectrum into six distinct peaks: V (881.9 eV), V' (887.2 eV), V'' (897.5 eV), u (900.6 eV), u' (906.5 eV), and u'' (916.2 eV). These peaks arise from spin–orbit interactions in the 3d and 4f orbitals between unpaired valence electrons, indicating the coexistence of two valence states of Ce [26]. Specifically, the peaks at V, V’’, and u correspond to Ce3+ 3d5/2 while the peaks at V’, u’ and u’’ are assigned to Ce4+ 3d3/2. The strong peak at 916.2 eV associated with Ce4+ 3d in CeO2 confirms that Ce4+ is the predominant valence state in CAOC-1. However, the observed 18.7 eV energy gap between V (881.9 eV) and u (900.6 eV) is attributed to valence switching in Ce, which occurs when Al3+ interacts with Ce4+, leading to the formation of Ce3+. This indicates the presence of Ce2O3 in CAOC-1. The presence of Ce3+ is likely correlated with oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface. The reversible redox transition between CeO2 and Ce2O3 plays a crucial role in enhancing the catalytic activity of CAOC-1 for 5-HMF oxidation. The Al 2p spectrum of CAOC-1 deconvolutes into two peaks at 73.11 eV and 73.78 eV, corresponding to Al2O3 and Al(OH)3, respectively (Fig. 6 b) [24]. This confirms the presence of amorphous Al species in CAOC-1, which are critically important for tuning product selectivity in both 5-HMF oxidation and fructose dehydration reactions. Deconvolution of the O 1 s spectrum reveals two peaks associated with lattice oxygen (528.2–529.2 eV) and surface oxygen species (530.1–531.5 eV) (Fig. 6 c). The oxygen vacancy peak is observed at around 530.5 eV. Based on peak intensities, CAOC-1 contains a higher proportion of surface oxygen relative to lattice oxygen. Surface oxygen, which includes hydroxyl groups and defect oxides, is more mobile and actively participates in oxidation reactions [45–47]. This explains why CAOC-1, which has a greater abundance of surface oxygen, outperforms other CAOC catalysts with lower surface oxygen content. Moreover, because of the efficient oxygen transfer from TBHP to Ce active sites, it has been demonstrated that surface oxygen or defective oxygen significantly accelerates the oxidation reaction. Additionally, surface oxygen is indicative of oxygen vacancies [48], which are closely linked to the efficient oxidation of 5-HMF into 2,5-FDCA. The C 1 s spectrum of CAOC-1 deconvolutes into three peaks assigned to C–C or C–H (283.8 eV), C–O–C or C–OH (284.7 eV), and CO (288.0 eV) groups (Fig. 6 d) [49]. The presence of various carbon species suggests that carbon plays a role beyond mere catalyst support in CAOC-1, potentially enhancing electron interactions among reacting groups [34]. The CAOC-1 catalyst exhibits oxygen defects due to interactions between Ce and Al oxides. The presence of surface oxygen vacancies is consistently confirmed by multiple techniques, including EPR analysis (g = 1.96), Raman spectroscopy, and XPS. These results strongly support the conclusion that oxygen vacancies play a crucial role in enhancing the catalytic efficiency of 5-HMF oxidation, highlighting their significance in catalytic performance. 3.1.7 NH3-TPD analysis of CAOC catalyst Because Lewis acidity plays a crucial role in the oxidation of 5-HMF to 2,5-FDCA, we characterized the strength and quantity of acid sites on the CAOC catalysts using ammonia as a probe molecule in temperature-programmed desorption (TPD). Acid strength in solid catalysts is classified based on ammonia desorption temperature as weak (<300 °C), moderate (300–500 °C), or strong (>500 °C) [49,50]. Desorption profiles for the CAOC materials are provided in Fig. S4 . For CAOC-1, two strong peaks appear below 300 °C, whereas for the other catalysts, two weaker peaks are observed. Additionally, all CAOC catalysts exhibit a peak between 300 °C and 500 °C, indicating that their acid sites possess weak to moderate acidity. The quantification of total acidity reveals a clear decreasing trend with an increase in the Ce/Al ratio, following the order CAOC-1 > CAOC-2 > CAOC-3 > CAOC-4 (Table 3 ). This trend may result from the formation of Lewis acid sites due to the imbalance of positive charges between Ce4+ and Al3+. Consequently, the highest total acidity of 1.170 mmol g−1 is observed in CAOC-1, where this charge imbalance is most pronounced. Since catalytic activity correlates strongly with total acidity, the efficiency of 5-HMF conversion to 2,5-FDCA follows the same trend. These results also align with BET surface area and pore size measurements. 3.2 Catalytic performance for oxidizing 5-HMF into 2,5-FDCA 3.2.1 Effect of various oxidants on 5-HMF oxidation Without any oxidant, the oxidation of 5-HMF using CAOC-1 did not proceed. To identify the most effective oxidizing agent, we tested three commonly used options—molecular oxygen, H2O2, and TBHP—for the oxidation of 5-HMF to 2,5-FDCA in DMSO at 120 °C for 24 h. A summary of product yields is provided in Table 4 . The reaction with molecular oxygen (balloon) resulted in the lowest 2,5-FDCA yield and selectivity (0.00 %). When H2O2 (9 mmol) was used, a yield of 1.48 % and selectivity 2.30 % were obtained; however, CAOC-1 also appeared to catalyze the decomposition of H2O2 into O2, making H2O2 unsuitable for this reaction system. Among the three oxidants, TBHP (9 mmol) provided the highest 2,5-FDCA yield (82.0 %) and selectivity (83.54 %), likely due to the stability of its radical species during the reaction. The use of peroxides significantly enhanced 2,5-FDCA formation, with TBHP proving to be a more effective oxidant than H2O2, likely due to its more stable radical species [22]. Interestingly, HMFCA was not detected in the oxidation products with any oxidant, suggesting that CAOC-1 preferentially catalyzes the DFF pathway rather than the HMFCA route in converting 5-HMF to 2,5-FDCA (Scheme 1). According to redox stoichiometry, the complete conversion of 5-HMF to 2,5-FDCA requires three equivalents of TBHP. Initially, we used approximately nine equivalents to ensure an excess of oxidant throughout the reaction. After the reaction, the remaining TBHP was measured at approximately 34.2 % of the initial amount, slightly lower than the expected stoichiometric excess (∼57.1 %), indicating that some TBHP decomposed into other products. Nevertheless, given the high 2,5-FDCA yield, TBHP was selected as the most suitable oxidant for 5-HMF oxidation over the CAOC-1 catalyst. 3.2.2 Effect of solvent on 5-HMF oxidation We conducted the oxidation of 5-HMF using CAOC-1 across a range of solvents, as solvent properties—including dielectric constant, polarity, acid-base behavior, and steric effects—significantly influence reaction efficiency and product selectivity. Table 5 summarizes the solvents used, their properties, and the corresponding 5-HMF conversions and oxidation product yields. The results indicate that reactions in tert-butanol, acetonitrile, or water result in low 5-HMF conversions (<36 %) and low 2,5-FDCA yields (<5 %), selectivity (<12 %), along with relatively high amounts of unwanted byproducts such as DFF and FFCA. Notably, differences in 5-HMF conversion and 2,5-FDCA yield are observed between acetonitrile and DMF despite their similar dielectric constants. This discrepancy can be attributed to differences in their chemical properties, such as polarity, solubility, boiling point, and hydrogen-bonding capacity. Except for water, these solvents possess relatively low dielectric constants, partially explaining the low 2,5-FDCA yields. However, DMF, with its higher boiling point (153 °C), greater solubility for reactants, and stronger hydrogen-bonding potential, may better stabilize certain intermediates, leading to distinct reaction pathways compared to acetonitrile (boiling point: 82 °C). Since the reaction temperature (120 °C) exceeds the boiling points of solvents like acetonitrile, water, and tert-butanol, incomplete reactions occur, resulting in 5-HMF conversions below 50 % and 2,5-FDCA yields below 5 %, selectivity of 12 %. In contrast, significantly higher 5-HMF conversions and 2,5-FDCA yields are obtained in DMF and DMSO, which have relatively high dielectric constants and strong polarity. Additional solvent properties, including solvent–solute interactions, viscosity, and nucleophilicity, may also contribute to the observed differences. Notably, the formation of unwanted byproducts is significantly reduced in these solvents, with virtually no DFF detected. Between DMF and DMSO, DMSO—having the higher dielectric constant—yields the highest 5-HMF conversion (98.16 %) and 2,5-FDCA yield (82.00 %) and selectivity (83.54 %). Given these superior results, along with DMSO’s high boiling point, strong polarity, low cost, and low toxicity, we selected it as the solvent for all subsequent reactions. As observed previously, HMFCA was not detected among the oxidation products, regardless of the solvent used. This further confirms that the CAOC-1-catalyzed oxidation of 5-HMF preferentially follows the DFF pathway, as depicted in Scheme 1 . This outcome is significant because it minimizes the number of oxidation intermediates, simplifying the subsequent isolation and purification of 2,5-FDCA when using CAOC-1 as a catalyst. 3.2.3 Effect of different CAOC catalysts on 5-HMF oxidation Due to the reactive aldehyde (–CHO) and hydroxyl (−OH) functional groups of 5-HMF, its oxidation can yield a variety of products, including DFF, FFCA, and 2,5-FDCA. Given the diversity of possible oxidation pathways, it is crucial to develop catalysts that maximize 5-HMF conversion while enhancing selectivity toward the desired product (e.g., 2,5-FDCA) and minimizing unwanted byproducts (e.g., DFF and FFCA). For all CAOC catalysts, 5-HMF utilization was nearly complete (∼98 %); however, product selectivity and yield varied significantly, strongly influenced by the relative abundance of Ce and Al species in the catalyst (Fig. 7 a). Specifically, the 2,5-FDCA yield was 56.8 % and selectivity (57.01 %) for CAOC-4 and increased linearly with a decreasing Ce/Al ratio, reaching 82.00 %, and selectivity (83.54 %) for CAOC-1. This trend suggests that an excessive Ce content relative to Al results in lower 2,5-FDCA yields, as seen in CAOC-4. Notably, when using Ce/C as the catalyst, a low 2,5-FDCA yield (15.12 %), and selectivity (17.13 %) was observed, along with high FFCA (38.23 %), (43.31 %), and DFF (5.65 %), (6.40 %) yields and selectivity’s respectively. Similarly, Al/C exhibited no 2,5-FDCA formation, a minor 5-HMF conversion (62.11 %), and a small DFF yield (3.91 %) and selectivity (6.30 %), producing a significant amount of side products, which suggests that it is not active for 2,5-FDCA synthesis. Conversely, as the Ce content decreases and Al is introduced in increasing amounts, bringing their relative abundance closer to 1:1, the 2,5-FDCA yield progressively improves. These findings indicate that Ce and Al act synergistically to create catalytically active sites, which underline the superior performance of mixed-oxide catalysts. Consequently, CAOC-1, which contains nearly equal amounts of Ce and Al, delivers the highest 2,5-FDCA yield and selectivity among the CAOC catalysts. Additionally, FFCA is the only detectable intermediate, appearing at a minimal yield of approximately 7.51 %, and selectivity 7.65 %. Beyond its optimal Ce/Al ratio, other factors also contribute to the exceptional catalytic performance of CAOC-1 in 5-HMF oxidation to 2,5-FDCA. These advantages stem from its unique structural and chemical properties, which arise from the precise combination and relative abundance of metal oxides. Unlike the other catalysts, CAOC-1 contains both crystalline and amorphous oxides, which provide reactive surface oxygen species and oxygen defects that facilitate ion mobility. Additionally, the significant charge imbalance in CAOC-1 enhances the formation of acid sites that participate in adduct formation during oxidation. CAOC-1 also exhibits the highest surface area, ensuring greater physical exposure of active sites to catalytic interactions compared to the other CAOC catalysts. These findings strongly align with the BET surface area and NH3-TPD surface acidity measurements. A comparison of product formation rates, expressed in terms of turnover frequency (TOF) values, further highlights the variability in catalytic performance among the CAOC catalysts due to their differing chemical and textural properties (Table 3). CAOC-1 exhibits the highest TOF of 0.0017 s−1, with TOF values following the order CAOC-1 > CAOC-2 > CAOC-3 > CAOC-4. This indicates that, under identical reaction conditions, CAOC-1 produces more 2,5-FDCA within a given reaction time than any of the other catalysts. Given its superior catalytic performance, CAOC-1 was selected as the optimal CAOC catalyst and used in all subsequent investigations. 3.2.4 Effect of mole ratio of TBHP to 5-HMF We refined the oxidant dosage by evaluating reactions at 5-HMF to TBHP ratios ranging from 1:5 to 1:12 using CAOC-1 (Fig. 7 b). The results indicate that increasing the TBHP concentration leads to modest but significant improvements in 5-HMF conversion and progressively higher 2,5-FDCA yields, selectivity’s, likely due to the enhanced generation of oxygen radicals that facilitate oxidation. Conversely, lower TBHP dosages result in reduced 5-HMF conversion, lower 2,5-FDCA yields, selectivity’s, and higher yields of undesired byproducts, DFF and FFCA. This suggests that an excess of TBHP is necessary [51]. However, there appears to be a limit to the amount of excess TBHP that can enhance the desired oxidation outcome. The data indicates that oxidation reactions conducted at HMF: TBHP molar ratios of 1:9 and 1:12 yield nearly identical 5-HMF conversion and 2,5-FDCA production. Given the minimal improvement observed at the 1:12 ratio and the importance of using only the necessary amount of TBHP, we identified the 1:9 ratio as the optimal oxidant dose. In selecting the 1:9 ratio, we considered multiple factors, including the target 2,5-FDCA yield and selectivity’s, byproduct formation, reaction condition optimization, and overall process efficiency. Based on these considerations, the 1:9 ratio was determined to be the most effective for further oxidation reactions. 3.2.5 Effect of various temperatures on the oxidation of 5-HMF We also investigated the effect of temperature on 5-HMF oxidation using CAOC-1. As shown in Fig. 7 c, both 5-HMF conversion and 2,5-FDCA yield, selectivity’s increase steadily with rising temperature from 80 °C to 140°C, indicating that the reaction is kinetically controlled. At the molecular level, higher temperatures lead to more frequent and energetic molecular collisions, thereby enhancing reaction progression. Consequently, the multi-step oxidation of 5-HMF to 2,5-FDCA proceeds more efficiently at elevated temperatures. In contrast, at lower temperatures, the reaction terminates prematurely, resulting in the accumulation of intermediates DFF and FFCA. However, excessively high temperatures may promote polymerization into humins or induce 5-HMF degradation [13,52], explaining the decline in 2,5-FDCA yield observed at 140 °C. Based on these findings, the optimal temperature for 5-HMF oxidation using CAOC-1 is 120 °C. 3.2.6 Effect of reaction time on the oxidation of 5-HMF The product profile of 5-HMF oxidation using CAOC-1 as a catalyst was monitored over time to track the evolution of the reaction mixture composition over a 30-h period. As shown in Fig. 7 d, after 6 h, 66.54 % of 5-HMF is converted, yields and selectivity’s DFF (17.16 %), (25.78 %), FFCA (10.65 %), (16.0 %), and 2,5-FDCA (31.79 %), (47.77 %) respectively. Over time, 5-HMF conversion and 2,5-FDCA yields, selectivity’s continue to increase, while DFF yield and selectivity declines to nearly zero by 24 h. Meanwhile, FFCA yield, and selectivity increases at 12 h but subsequently declines, remaining at a minimal yet detectable level. This suggests that the conversion of FFCA to 2,5-FDCA is the rate-limiting step in the overall oxidation of 5-HMF [53]. Based on the product profile at different time points, DFF and FFCA appear to be key reaction intermediates in the formation of 2,5-FDCA. Furthermore, with TBHP as the oxidant, the reaction likely follows a well-defined sequence: initial oxidation of 5-HMF to DFF, followed by the conversion of DFF to FFCA, and ultimately, the oxidation of FFCA to 2,5-FDCA. This sequence aligns with the temporal product distribution and implies that the aldehyde group of 5-HMF is oxidized before the hydroxymethyl group. Extending the reaction time beyond 24 h results in only a marginal increase in 2,5-FDCA yield and selectivity, indicating that the reaction has effectively reached completion. 3.2.7 Effect of loading a catalyst We also investigated the effect of CAOC-1 loading on the product distribution of 5-HMF oxidation to further optimize reaction conditions. A range of catalyst loadings (10–100 mg) was tested, and the resulting products were analyzed (Fig. 8 a). The results show that both 5-HMF conversion and 2,5-FDCA yield, selectivity increase with catalyst loading up to 50–60 mg. However, further increasing the catalyst load to 100 mg leads to a decline in 2,5-FDCA yield and selectivity, likely due to the formation of undesired side products [54]. Conversely, lower catalyst loads (10 mg and 30 mg) result in substantial yields and selectivity’s of DFF and FFCA. These findings suggest that a sufficient number of active sites is required to facilitate the multi-step conversion of 5-HMF to 2,5-FDCA, with an optimal catalyst loading of approximately 50 mg. 3.2.8 Catalyst recovery and reuse Catalyst recovery and reuse are critical aspects of heterogeneous catalysis, representing a key advantage over homogeneous systems. To evaluate the reusability of CAOC-1, we conducted multiple cycles of recovery and redeployment under optimal reaction conditions: DMSO as the solvent, a 1:9 5-HMF: TBHP ratio, 24 h reaction time, 120 °C temperature, and 50 mg of CAOC-1. After each cycle, the reaction products were analyzed, and the recovered catalyst was thoroughly washed with water and ethanol and then dried at 100 °C overnight to ensure optimal reusability. As shown in Fig. 8 b, 5-HMF conversion remained nearly constant over five reuse cycles, while 2,5-FDCA yield, and selectivity exhibited a slight decline after each cycle, likely due to partial catalyst deactivation. However, over five cycles, the 2,5-FDCA yield, and selectivity decreased by only ∼5 %, indicating that CAOC-1 retains high catalytic stability and activity under reuse conditions. After the fifth cycle (120 °C, 24 h), the spent catalyst was characterized using XRD, SEM, and XPS, with the results presented in Figs. S5, S6, and S13 . The XRD spectra and SEM images reveal a noticeable increase in amorphous characteristics, which can be attributed to the formation of humins on the catalyst surface during oxidation [12,16]. Additionally, due to the limited water content in the aqueous TBHP system, organic humins may form within the reaction medium [11]. The XRD spectra ( Fig. S5 ) shows broad peaks, suggesting the presence of humins. This observation implies that the minor decrease in 2,5-FDCA yield is likely caused by the adsorption of impurities, including reactants, intermediates, and products, onto the catalyst surface [55]. Humins can hinder 5-HMF oxidation by blocking active sites, leading to reduced catalytic performance and gradual deactivation [56]. Furthermore, we observed an amorphous layer on the catalyst surface but did not detect any significant changes in the SEM images of the reused catalyst ( Fig. S13 ). The XPS analysis confirmed that the chemical binding states of the elements remain unchanged even after multiple reaction cycles ( Fig. S6 ). The surface elemental composition, as displayed in Table S3 , showed no significant loss, indicating that the chemical structure of the catalyst remained largely intact after five catalytic cycles, demonstrating excellent chemical stability. Additionally, we conducted inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) analysis to precisely determine the Ce and Al content in both fresh and reused catalysts. As shown in Table S2 , the Ce content decreased from 66.16 to 59.28 mg/L, while the Al content declined from 31.65 to 28.74 mg/L after five runs. This minimal metal loss may be attributed to the deposition of organic reaction intermediates, carbonaceous species (including humins), and other reaction products on the catalyst surface during the reaction cycles. Another contributing factor could be the gradual loss of catalyst mass during recovery and reuse. Overall, these characterization results indicate that the CAOC-1 catalyst exhibits high stability and is well-suited for repeated use in catalytic processes. Notably, CAOC-1 does not require a base for the oxidation of 5-HMF to 2,5-FDCA. This is likely due to the large amount of mesoporous amorphous carbon support, high surface area, and significant surface acidity, which induce electronic changes that modify how the substrate binds and interacts with metal oxides on the catalyst surface [57–59]. These factors facilitate oxidation without the need for a base. Based on these findings, CAOC-1 emerges as a highly promising catalyst for the synthesis of 2,5-FDCA as a platform chemical. 3.3 One-pot conversion of fructose into 2,5-FDCA 3.3.1 “One-pot, two-step” conversion of fructose into 2,5-FDCA using CAOC catalysts To explore the potential of CAOC-1 in biomass conversion to 2,5-FDCA, we investigated its application in a one-pot reaction setup using fructose as the starting substrate. This approach offers advantages in terms of process economics and operational simplicity by eliminating the need for 5-HMF isolation and purification. However, direct oxidation of sugars often leads to multiple side products, making high-yield, and selective production of a specific target compound particularly challenging. For successful implementation, the two-step transformation—dehydration of fructose to 5-HMF followed by oxidation of 5-HMF to 2,5-FDCA—must proceed efficiently using a single catalyst within the same reaction medium and with minimal changes in reaction inputs. In the first step, fructose dehydration to 5-HMF was carried out at 120 °C under an N2 atmosphere in DMSO for 2 h. As shown in Fig. 8 c, all CAOC catalysts demonstrated good fructose conversion and 5-HMF yields, but CAOC-1 exhibited the highest yield (∼95.23 %), and selectivity (∼97.53 %). This superior performance is attributed to its high surface area, carbon support, synergistically active metals (Ce and Al), and amorphous Al(OH)3 characteristics, which promote highly selective dehydration. In the second step, after completing the dehydration reaction, TBHP was added dropwise over 24 h under an air atmosphere to oxidize 5-HMF to 2,5-FDCA. The product distribution for this one-pot, two-step conversion is summarized in Fig. 8 d. While all CAOC catalysts facilitated the reaction, CAOC-1 achieved the highest overall 2,5-FDCA yield (∼80.26 %), and selectivity (∼83.94 %) from fructose. In contrast, other CAOC catalysts showed a gradual decline in 2,5-FDCA yield, selectivity, accompanied by increasing amounts of DFF and FFCA as byproducts. Overall, these results confirm that CAOC-1 effectively catalyzes both the dehydration of fructose to 5-HMF and the subsequent oxidation of 5-HMF to 2,5-FDCA, making it a strong candidate for the commercial production of 2,5-FDCA from biomass. 3.3.2 Comparison with other catalysts for fructose to 2,5-FDCA conversion To further contextualize the achievements of this study, we compiled and summarized literature reports on the sequential conversion of fructose to 2,5-FDCA using heterogeneous catalysts, along with their corresponding 2,5-FDCA yields (Table 6 ). Notably, only a limited number of studies have been published on the conversion of fructose to 2,5-FDCA. Among these, CAOC-1 demonstrates the highest overall yield (∼80.26 %). Furthermore, the one-pot process required to achieve this remarkably high yield offers simpler operation and milder reaction conditions compared to previously reported heterogeneous catalysts. Many of these catalysts necessitate temperatures of 130 °C or higher and prolonged reaction times (16–30 h) [37,62,63]. Meanwhile, some catalysts that operate at lower temperatures (80–100 °C) require the use of two different catalysts at high relative doses [14]. Additionally, since these reactions involve two distinct catalytic steps, the need to remove and replace catalysts complicates the process [63]. Moreover, certain catalysts require temperature adjustments between steps, further increasing process complexity. In another report, a one-pot, a single-step system employing two catalysts yielded only 46 % 2,5-FDCA while using an expensive ionic liquid as the solvent. Other catalyst systems rely on the relatively toxic solvent DMF [63]. In contrast, CAOC-1 offers several operational advantages: (1) A consistent and relatively mild temperature for both dehydration and oxidation steps. (2) A lower catalyst dosage relative to fructose. (3) A cost-effective, non-toxic solvent system. (4) Seamless transition from dehydration to oxidation, requiring only a shift from an N2 atmosphere to TBHP addition. Furthermore, CAOC-1 is synthesized using inexpensive and widely available non-noble metals anchored on glucose-derived carbon, reinforcing its viability as a promising catalyst for the commercial production of 2,5-FDCA from biomass. 3.3.3 Catalyzed fructose dehydration and 5-HMF oxidation utilizing CAOC-1: a proposed mechanism To provide insight into the conversion of fructose into 5-HMF and subsequently to 2,5-FDCA, we propose possible reaction mechanisms based on catalyst characterization and identified reaction intermediates ( Fig. S7 ). For the dehydration of fructose to 5-HMF using CAOC-1 in DMSO, the reaction begins with the protonation of the oxide (O2–) group of DMSO by surface oxide and –OH groups in CAOC-1, forming the cationic intermediate (I) [20,64]. This suggests that both CAOC-1 and DMSO play critical roles in fructose dehydration [37]. The reaction proceeds as cationic DMSO forms hydrogen bonds with fructose, leading to the formation of intermediate (II). Subsequent cyclization of the five-membered ring (III) occurs, with the removal of three water molecules facilitated by Brønsted and Lewis acid sites in CAOC-1, ultimately yielding 5-HMF. The oxidation of 5-HMF to 2,5-FDCA is depicted in Fig. S8 and occurs in two main stages, where both the CAOC-1 catalyst and TBHP play crucial roles. In the first stage, 5-HMF undergoes rapid oxidation to 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF) as its aldehyde functional group interacts with the surface of CAOC-1, hydroxyl radicals (∙OH), and tert-butoxy radicals ((CH3)3CO) generated from TBHP under heating conditions. This results in the formation of H2O, tert-butanol (T-BuOH), and the radical form of 5-HMF. The radical oxygen species from 5-HMF then interact with tert-butoxy radicals to form peroxy species, which subsequently decompose to yield DFF. Simultaneously, tert-butoxy radicals (CH3)3CO) combine with hydrogen radicals (H∙) to generate tert-butanol. In the second stage, Ce4+ oxidizes DFF to FFCA and is reduced to Ce3+. The oxidation of FFCA to 2,5-FDCA follows the same pathway, where Ce4+ facilitates oxidation and is again reduced to Ce3+. TBHP re-oxidizes Ce3+ back to Ce4+, ensuring continuous catalytic activity. Additionally, Al contributes by enhancing acidity and basicity, promoting the redox cycling of Ce4+/Ce3+ and stabilizing oxidation–reduction processes. This cascade of oxidation and reduction steps, initiated by the reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+, generates oxygen vacancies, which play a crucial role in catalytic activity [63]. The high surface concentration of Ce3+ species in CAOC-1 provides a maximum density of oxygen vacancies, further enhancing catalytic performance. The redox functionality of CAOC-1 can be summarized as Ce4+ ⇋ Ce3+ and Ce3+ ⇋ Ce4+, mediated by TBHP and Al species in conjunction with carbon [15,65]. The synergistic interplay between Ce and Al facilitates oxygen mobility, enhances redox activity, and creates additional oxygen vacancies, which are vital for the overall reaction mechanism. The presence of Al and amorphous carbon in CAOC-1 improves acidity and basicity due to their high surface area and textural properties. Furthermore, Al(OH)3 and Al2O3 act as promoters, increasing catalytic activity and stability [66]. Overall, the bifunctional nature of CeO2, Al2O3, Al(OH)3, and amorphous carbon in CAOC-1 enhances the catalytic efficiency and stability of the one-pot, two-step conversion of fructose to 2,5-FDCA. Moreover, bifunctional catalyst systems that facilitate dehydration and oxidation catalyze the one-pot synthesis of 2,5-FDCA from fructose. As per the above dehydration and oxidation discussion part of the reaction mechanism, we proposed a detailed one-pot reaction mechanism of fructose to 2,5-FDCA based on experimental and characterization support from the CAOC-1 bifunctional catalysis study ( Fig. S9 ). These proposed mechanisms demonstrate the effectiveness of CAOC-1 in facilitating this transformation. 4 Conclusions We successfully developed a bimetallic heterogeneous oxide catalyst using the inexpensive, non-noble metals Ce and Al, supported on carbon derived from renewable biomass. The CAOC-1 catalyst exhibits outstanding efficiency in converting 5-HMF into the highly valuable industrial chemical 2,5-FDCA, achieving the highest reported 2,5-FDCA yield and selectivity from fructose among known heterogeneous catalysts. This remarkable performance is attributed to its unique chemical and textural properties. CAOC-1 can be effectively implemented in a one-pot, two-step reaction system operating under mild conditions, requiring only minor modifications to reaction inputs to facilitate both fructose dehydration and 5-HMF oxidation. Oxidation without a base is possibly facilitated by the oxygen vacancies in the CAOC-1 catalyst, the varied oxidation states, and the distinct redox conditions of Ce and Al on carbon. The proposed reaction mechanism highlights the synergistic activity of the catalyst. With its superior catalytic performance and simple process requirements, CAOC-1 stands among the most promising catalysts for the sustainable production of 2,5-FDCA from renewable resources. Furthermore, by eliminating complex intermediate, solvent, and catalyst separation steps, this innovative reaction approach significantly reduces operating costs and energy consumption. coredata.dc:description: Using tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) as a low-cost oxidant, we synthesized, characterized, and evaluated heterogeneous bifunctional oxide catalysts composed of the non-noble metals Ce and Al in specific molar ratios, supported on glucose-derived carbon, for the conversion of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (2,5-FDCA) in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO). TBHP offers two advantages: it functions as an oxidant and generates tert-butanol, a valuable industrial solvent. We fully investigated catalyst loading, temperature, 5-HMF:TBHP molar ratio, reaction time, and reuse impact on product yield while correlating with the catalyst’s textural and chemical properties. CAOC-1, the best catalyst, achieved 98 % conversion, 82.0 % yield, and 83.54 % selectivity of 2,5-FDCA in optimal conditions (5-HMF (1 mmol), TBHP (9 mmol), DMSO (5 gm), CAOC-1 (50 mg), Temp (120 °C), 24 h), with minimal yield reduction over five reuse cycles. We used the bifunctional CAOC-1 in a one-pot, two-step system to directly transform fructose to 2,5-FDCA under mild conditions (fructose (1 mmol), TBHP (9 mmol), DMSO (5 gm), CAOC-1 (50 mg), temp (120 °C), 26 h) with minimal process modifications. The yield and selectivity of 2,5-FDCA were 80.26 % and 83.94 %, respectively. We proposed mechanistic pathways for dehydration and oxidation reactions, highlighting the catalyst’s bifunctional nature in facilitating high 2,5-FDCA yields from fructose and 5-HMF. The formation of the distinct redox environment of Ce and Al on carbon, the various oxidation states, and the oxygen vacancies in the CAOC-1 catalyst—all of which most likely operate as base-free oxidation active sites. One-pot reaction processes involve bifunctional CAOC-1 catalysts, –OH, and redox active sites (Ce), which play a significant role in dehydration and oxidation reactions, respectively. 2,5-FDCA is crucial to produce polyethylene 2,5-furandicarboxylate (PEF), a sustainable bioplastic and alternative to PET.
